newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan OKs $200 million in foreign telecom investments.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan OKs $200 million in foreign telecom investments.

text.p: Taiwan approved three foreign-led telecommunications ventures Tuesday, including one led by a unit of AT&T Corp., to invest a combined $200 million in the island's fast-liberalising telecommunications market.
The Economics Ministry's investment commission approved a plan by AT&T Wireless Services of Taiwan and partner Cheung Hing Development Ltd to invest $65.46 million.
It also approved a plan by Sweden's Telia Overseas AB to invest $58.18 million, a ministry statement said.
The ministry also gave a go-ahead to Hong Kong-based New World Telephone Ltd., a unit of New World Development Co. Ltd., to invest $76.36 million in local value-added telecommunication services.
These can include Internet services, airline reservations systems and teleconferencing.
Reforms passed in January give unprecedented though still limited access to the market by foreign interests, which had long been barred outright from telecom operations.
Foreigners now can own up to 20 percent of any Taiwan firm offering common-carrier services, a ratio design to ensure local control.
Foreign companies are free to own and operate value-added services.
Taiwan is also reviewing bids by 17 consortiums, including one led by AT&T, to operate eight lucrative mobile telephone franchises, with a decision expected by year's end.
Tuesday's approvals were not directly related to that competition.
Mobile telephone service is one of several telecom sectors liberalised by parliament in January, opening them up for private and limited foreign investments.
Before the reforms, telephone, data and other telecom services had been monopolised by the government.
